skill.name: connecting-to-logseq
skill.description: Manages connections to Logseq graphs via HTTP API, CLI, or MCP Server. Auto-invokes when users mention connecting to Logseq, API tokens, graph paths, connection issues, or backend configuration. Handles backend detection, environment setup, and connectivity troubleshooting.

security_audit.summary: This skill manages connections to Logseq graphs using standard Claude Code tools. It reads/writes configuration files, accesses environment variables for API tokens, and makes localhost HTTP calls to the Logseq API. No malicious patterns, obfuscation, or data exfiltration detected. Token handling follows security best practices.

evidence.description: Allowed tools include Read, Write, Edit for configuration management
Config file references ${LOGSEQ_API_TOKEN} syntax for env var substitution
Logseq HTTP API server on localhost only

content.value_statement: Users need to integrate Claude with their Logseq knowledge graphs for querying and writing data. This skill provides automated connection management across HTTP API, CLI, and MCP Server backends with built-in troubleshooting support.
actual_capabilities: Auto-detect available Logseq backends (HTTP API, CLI, MCP)
Configure and validate Logseq API connections
Set up environment variables and configuration files
Troubleshoot connection issues and authentication errors
Execute Datalog queries against Logseq graphs
Manage graph paths and backend selection
limitations: Requires Logseq to be running for HTTP API and MCP backends
CLI backend has limited write capabilities
Cannot connect to remote Logseq instances over the internet
Does not create or manage Logseq graphs directly

use_cases.title: Query your knowledge base
use_cases.description: Ask Claude to search your Logseq graph using Datalog queries and retrieve structured information.

use_cases.title: Write notes to Logseq

prompt_templates.title: Basic connection
prompt_templates.prompt: Connect me to my Logseq graph at /path/to/my-graph and test the connection.

prompt_templates.title: Query data
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all pages in my Logseq graph tagged with "Project" and list their titles.

prompt_templates.title: Write content
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new page called "Meeting Notes" in my Logseq graph with today's date and add a block with my action items.

prompt_templates.title: Troubleshoot

best_practices: Store your Logseq API token in environment variables, never in config files or code
Always verify your Logseq HTTP API is enabled before attempting connections
Use absolute paths for graph directories to avoid relative path issues
Restart Logseq after changing API settings to ensure changes take effect
anti_patterns: Hardcoding API tokens in configuration files or scripts
Using relative paths for graph directories in automated workflows
Attempting connections without verifying Logseq is running
Sharing Logseq API tokens in commits, logs, or chat messages

faq.question: What backends does this skill support?
faq.answer: HTTP API (requires running Logseq), CLI (offline support), and MCP Server (Claude-native tools).

faq.question: Does the skill work with remote Logseq instances?
faq.answer: No. The HTTP API only listens on localhost. Logseq does not currently support remote API connections.

faq.question: What permissions does this skill need?
faq.answer: Read, Write, Edit, Bash, Grep, Glob for managing configurations and executing connection scripts.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. All API calls stay on localhost. Tokens are handled via environment variables, never stored in plain text.

faq.question: Why am I getting connection refused errors?
faq.answer: Common causes: Logseq not running, HTTP API not enabled, wrong port (default 12315), or firewall blocking localhost.

faq.question: How is this different from other data skills?
faq.answer: This skill is specialized for Logseq's unique architecture including Datalog queries, datascript schema, and MD-to-DB migration paths.
